questions.text: A newborn has a deformity in the left arm as shown in the image below. The child was born after a difficult vaginal delivery. Which of the following nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing a claw hand with a supinated forearm and the flexed elbow is likely suggestive of Klumpke's palsy. The C8-T1 nerve roots are affected in this condition. 

Klumpke's palsy occurs following an injury to the 8th cervical nerve and the 1st thoracic nerve. It is commonly seen after deliveries involving excessive traction on the brachial plexus. It results in a paralyzed hand where the intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and the ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8) are mainly affected.

Clinically, the baby lies with the forearm supinated and the elbow flexed. There is a loss of intrinsic muscle power and reflexes in the hand. There may be a unilateral Horner’s syndrome, characterized by ipsilateral ptosis and miosis if the sympathetic fibers of the 1st thoracic root are also injured.

Immobilization and prevention of contractures form the mainstay of treatment in Klumpke's palsy.

The image given below shows clinical features seen in Klumpke's palsy.

Other options: 

Option A: Median nerve palsy presentation depends on the level of the lesion. Low lesions present as impaired abduction of the thumb and loss of sensation over the radial 3 1/2 digits. High lesions will have the features of low lesions, but will also have paralysis of the radial wrist flexors and forearm pronator muscles. The hand will be held with the ulnar fingers flexed and the index straight (pointing index sign). 

Option B: In a total plexus injury, C5 - T1 are injured. Here, the baby's arm is flail and pale. There is paralysis of all the fingers and unilateral Horner's syndrome. 

Option D: C5 - C6 injury is seen in Erb's palsy. It is typically seen in overweight babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery. There is paralysis of the abductors, external rotators of the shoulder, and the supinators. The arm will be held to the side in internal rotation and pronation with loss of finger extension.

The following image shows the clinical presentation of Erb's palsy.

Related Pearl: Erb's and Klumpke's Palsies.

Features Erb's palsy Klumpke's Palsy
Causes

Undue separtion of head and shoulder. Upper plexus root involved. 

Eg.Shoulder dystocia at delivery, motor vehicle accidents

Hyperabduction of shoulder. Lower plexus root involved.

Eg. Difficult breech delivery, Holding on to something (e.g. a branch) during a fall, Cervical rib syndrome, Scalene syndrome
Nerves roots  C5 and C6 C8 and T1
Muscles involved

Deltoid, Supraspinatus - loss of abduction 

Infraspinatus - loss of lateral rotation 

Biceps brachii - loss of flexion and supination 

 All intrinsic muscles of the hand
Position of the upper limb/hand Policeman's tip/Waiter's tip/ Porter's tip position Claw hand
Sensory loss +/- Along the outer aspect of the arm Along the medial border of forearm and hand
ANS signs  Absent

Horner syndrome

questions.text: A child, upon ingestion of shellfish, developed a tingling sensation in the mouth, swelling of the face, lips, and tongue, and also complained of abdominal pain and dizziness. What type of reaction is this?
questions.solution:
This is an example of an anaphylactic reaction after ingestion of an allergen(shellfish). It is an IgE mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction. 

The primary mediators are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes. The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mild rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Prototypical Disorders

Immediate (type I) hypersensitivity

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Anaphylaxis; allergies; bronchial asthma,Atopic dermatitis

Antibody-mediated (type II)hypersensitivity

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia; Goodpasture syndrome

Immune complex-mediated (type III) hypersensitivity

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Systemic lupus erythematosus; serum sickness; Arthus reaction

Cell-mediated (type IV) hypersensitivity

Activated T lymphocytes →

(1) the release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation;

(2) T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Contact dermatitis; multiple sclerosis; type 1 diabetes; tuberculosis

questions.text: Which is the largest human plasma lipoprotein?
questions.solution:
Chylomicrons are the largest among plasma lipoproteins, which are especially rich in triacylglycerol.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman receiving cyclosporin A after renal transplantation develops multiple and bilateral breast lumps that regress after cessation of treatment. ​Biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Almost half the women receiving cyclosporin A after renal transplantation develop multiple and bilateral fibroadenomas that regress after cessation of treatment.

Fibroadenomas are the most common benign tumor of the female breast. They are frequently multiple and bilateral and usually occur in women<30 years of age. They are called "breast mouse" due to their high mobility within the breast.

Complex fibroadenomas are grouped with “proliferative changes without atypia” and are associated with 1.5-2 times increased risk of subsequent cancer. Complex fibroadenomas contain cysts larger than 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine change.

Histological image of Fibroadenoma showing proliferation of ducts arranged in intracanalicular (compressed) and pericanalicular pattern surrounded by fibromyxoid stroma.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the dermatology OPD with a history of itchy hypopigmented patches over her chest for 6 months. A KOH mount is prepared with the skin scraping sample, which on microscopy reveals a characteristic appearance as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the KOH mount preparation showing the spaghetti and meatball appearance suggest pityriasis versicolor.

Pityriasis Versicolor is a chronic superficial infection of the stratum corneum caused by Malassezia globosa and Malassezia furfur. The most common site involves the neck, chest, back, and upper arms. The lesions often appear as hypopigmented areas.

The KOH mount reveals fungal hyphae that are short and thick (like spaghetti or banana) and many variously sized spores (like meatballs or grapes) referred to as spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance.

Treatment includes topical azoles or terbinafine for 2 weeks.

The image below shows the hypopigmented lesions of P. versicolor over the chest.

Electron microscopic image of Malassezia furfur

questions.text: A person develops headache and breathlessness on a trekking expedition following rapid ascent to over 3000 metres above the sea level. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of headache and breathlessness following rapid ascent indicate acute mountain/altitude sickness and IV digoxin is not used to treat this condition. 

On ascent to high altitudes, the low partial pressure of oxygen leads to hypoxia and systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue and the following symptoms are seen:

  • Headache
  • Irritation
  • Insomnia
  • Breathlessness
  • Nausea and vomiting

Treatment involves administration of oxygen, descent to a lower altitude and administration of acetazolamide. Acetazolamide counteracts hypoxia by stimulating respiration and also reduces the formation of cerebrospinal fluid, thereby reducing intracranial tension.

Portable hyperbaric chambers are increasingly being used in the treatment of high-altitude illnesses when rapid descent is not possible. These chambers are available in armed forces hospitals in high-altitude areas.

questions.text: The following postmortem staining is seen in ____?
questions.solution:
The image above is characteristic of Cherry red postmortem lividity. It is seen in carbon monoxide poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery?
questions.solution:
Cavernous sinus thrombosis is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery(FESS).

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball
  • Nasal polyps
  • Mucocele 
  • Control of epistaxis 
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus
  • Barotrauma sinusitis (pain in the face during descent in aircraft or descent whilst scuba diving)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in myasthenia gravis (MG).

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR.

Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increases on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal.

questions.text: Spot the wrongly matched arthropod and disease.
questions.solution:
Chagas disease is transmitted by the reduviid bugs or kissing bugs.

Blackflies transmit onchocerciasis

Related Pearl: Arthropod-borne Diseases

Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever, oraya fever.

Reduviid bug (Kissing bug/Triatominae) Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, Kyasanur forest disease, tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF)
Soft tick Relapsing fever
Ixodes tick Lyme disease, babesiosis and anaplasmosis.
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus
House mouse mite Rickettsial pox
Itch mite Scabies
Cyclops Guinea worm disease, fish tapeworm
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrans, jigger or chigoe flea) Tungiasis, ulcers in feet/nails.

questions.text: Cryoprecipitate has all the following components except
questions.solution:
Cryoprecipitate does not contain factor IX.

Components of cryoprecipitate are

  • Factor VIII
  • Factor XIII
  • Fibrinogen
  • Fibronectin
  • Von Willebrand factor

Therefore it can be used in patients with hemophilia A, factor XIII deficiency, hypofibrinogenemia, and von Willebrand disease.

Related Pearl: Blood components

Component Volume     (1 unit) Content Clinical response, increase in  Storage temperature Shelf-life

Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) 180 ml RBCs

Hb by 1 g/dl

Hematocrit by 3%

1° to 6°C

ACD/CPD-21 days, CPD-A-35 days, additive-42 days
Random donor platelets (RDP) 50-70 ml Platelets platelet count by 5000-10,000/µL 20 to 24°C 5 days
Single donor apheretic platelets (SDP*) 200-400 ml Platelets platelet count by 30,000/µL
Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) 200-250 ml Coagulation factors, protein C, protein S, anti thrombin coagulation factors by 2% -18 to -30°C 1 year
Cryoprecipitate 10-15 ml fibrinogen, factor VIII, VWF 80 IU Factor VIII -18 °C 1 years

 

*SDP is obtained by collecting multiple units of platelets from a single donor using apheretic technology. 

1 SDP = 6 RDP

questions.text: Which of the following is the first line of treatment for von Willebrand disease?
questions.solution:
Desmopressin is the first line of treatment for von Willebrand disease.

Desmopressin (DDAVP) acts on endothelial V2 receptors causing the release of VWF and factor VIII from endothelial stores.

DDAVP can be given intravenously or by an intranasal spray. Side effects: Tachyphylaxis and hyponatremia. 

VWF concentrate is given for severe diseases or for major procedures.

Antifibrinolytic therapy (tranexamic acid or ε-aminocaproic acid) is used for the prevention and treatment of mucosal bleeding.

questions.text: A 66-year-old chronic smoker who is diagnosed with small cell carcinoma of the lung presents to the ER with complaints of nausea, confusion,  and dizziness. After the initial workup, he is diagnosed to have the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). The SIADH is characterized by:

choices.text: Hyponatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L
Hypernatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L

questions.solution:
The syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) is associated with increased urinary excretion of sodium, thereby leading to hyponatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L.

 Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with SIADH due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. 

Patients usually present with hyponatremia with a euvolemic status. If hyponatremia develops acutely, signs and symptoms may include mild headache, confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, coma, and convulsions. Chronic hyponatremia allows cerebral adaptation, and the patients are asymptomatic despite the hyponatremia.

Laboratory findings in SIADH include:

  • Hyponatremia: serum Na+<135 mEq/L
  • Urinary loss of Na+ >25 mEq per day or >40 mEq/L 
  • Urinary osmolality is >100 mOsm/kg
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are low, usually <10 mg/dL
  • Serum K+ and serum bicarbonate are normal

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his scrotum. He previously had similar pain that would subside spontaneously but the pain this time is unbearable.  Physical examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum. Cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of testicular torsion. In cases of high clinical suspicion, the next best step is to explore surgically.

Clinical features of testicular torsion are painful scrotal swelling, erythema, nausea, and vomiting. Testis seems high in the scrotum and the twisted cord can sometimes be palpated.

Signs seen on torsion of the testis are:

  • Deming’s sign: Spasm of the cremaster muscle due to twisting of the spermatic cord causes the affected testis to be positioned higher than the normal testis.
  • Angell’s sign: The testis on the normal side lies horizontally because of the mesorchium between the testis and epididymis.
  • Cremastic reflex: Absent on the side of the affected testis

Doppler ultrasound scanning can confirm the absence of the blood supply to the affected testis, but the false positives are high and hence it is not routinely recommended. The typical window of opportunity for surgical intervention and testicular salvage is 6 hours from onset of pain.

Testicular torsion is a clinical diagnosis and an emergency, therefore no time is wasted in performing the other investigations.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presented to the clinic with reddening and itching over the left breast as shown in the figure. Mammogram showed the presence of microcalcifications in the left breast. Histopathology shows the presence of large pale vacuolated cells with round nuclei in the epithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and histology are diagnostic of Paget's disease of the breast. 

Paget’s disease is a superficial manifestation of underlying malignancy.

Clinically it presents as a chronic, eczematous eruption of the nipple which may progress to ulceration. In the majority of patients, there is also an underlying breast lump. This lump is usually DCIS. Less commonly it can also be invasive ductal carcinoma.

A nipple biopsy specimen will show a population of cells that are identical to the underlying malignant cells. The presence of large, pale, vacuolated cells (Paget cells) with round or oval nuclei is pathognomonic for this condition.

Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with lumpectomy or mastectomy.

Paget's disease can be often confused with superficial spreading melanoma. Paget's disease shows positive immunostaining with carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), while superficial spreading melanoma is positive for S-100 antigen.

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 6-year-old unimmunized child to the ER with complaints of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. Examination reveals a bull-neck appearance and a pseudomembrane over the tonsils that bleeds when removed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 6-year-old suffering from fever, cough, and shortness of breath with a pseudomembrane and bull neck appearance on examination is suggestive of diphtheria.

Diphtheria is caused by the bacteria Corynebacterium diphtheriae which spreads via droplets through the respiratory tract (most important), cutaneous lesions, and fomites.

Respiratory tract diphtheria is characterized by a thick, adherent pseudomembrane (grey or white) on one/both tonsils and adjacent pharynx. Underlying soft tissue oedema and enlarged lymph nodes can cause a bull-neck appearance. 

Patients with laryngeal diphtheria are at risk for suffocation because of local soft-tissue oedema and airway obstruction by the diphtheritic membrane.

Management includes antitoxin therapy as a single empirical dose of 20,000-100,000 units and antibiotics. Penicillin G/ Benzylpenicillin is the drug of choice for diphtheria. However, in case of an allergy to the same, Erythromycin is used. Other antibiotics used are clindamycin, rifampin, and tetracycline.

A greyish-white membrane forms over the tonsils in the oropharynx and spreads to the soft palate and posterior pharyngeal wall. The membrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils onto the soft palate and is dirty grey. It is adherent, and its removal leaves a bleeding surface. In the larynx, the diphtheritic membrane may cause airway obstruction.

Cervical lymph nodes, particularly the jugulodigastric, become enlarged and tender, sometimes presenting a bull-neck appearance. The patient is ill and toxaemic, but fever seldom rises above 38°C.

D/D for membrane over tonsil:

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukaemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Aphthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

Other options :

Option A: Infectious mononucleosis most commonly presents in adolescents with initial symptoms of fever, sore throat, fatigue, myalgia, and malaise. Pharyngitis is often the most prominent sign, with the enlargement of the tonsils and an exudate resembling that of streptococcal pharyngitis. It can be associated with tender, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. 

Option B: In acute membranous tonsillitis, exudates from the crypts coalesce to form a membrane on the surface of the tonsil that is easily wiped away without any bleeding.

Option D: Oral candidiasis/Oral thrush associated with candida albicans presents as white plaque-like lesions with cheesy exudate on an erythematous mucosa. They are typically painful and can be easily brushed off.

questions.text: During an intra-oral procedure, the resident uses the given suture material to place sutures on the soft palate. What is this suture material called?
questions.solution:
The suture material shown in the image is plain catgut. It is a yellowish absorbable suture material. 

Chromic catgut is brownish in colour.

Vicryl is a violet-coloured absorbable suture material.

Silk is a black-coloured, multifilament, natural, braided, and non-absorbable suture material. It is derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva.

Prolene is a blue coloured, monofilament, non-absorbable suture.

Related Pearl: Suture materials

Ligate superficial vessels

Suture subcutaneous tissues, stomas and other tissues that heal rapidly

Gut and biliary anastomoses

Subcuticular wound

Monofilament

Dyed or undyed

Used in tissues where slightly longer wound support is required

questions.text: Identify the type of adherent placenta___
questions.solution:
The given illustration with villi invading the myometrium depicts placenta increta.

Types of adherent placenta:

  • Placenta accreta: Indicates that villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta: Villi actually invade the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta: Defines villi that penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

questions.text: Chadwick sign is seen in _____
questions.solution:
Jacquemier’s or Chadwick’s sign is the dusky hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall visible at around 8th week of pregnancy. The discolouration is due to local vascular congestion.

During pregnancy, there is increased vascularity and hyperemia in the skin and muscles of the perineum and vulva. This increased vascularity prominently affects the vagina and cervix and results in the bluish tint of the vagina and ectocervix which is characteristic of the Chadwick sign.

questions.text: Diagnostic laparoscopy was performed on a patient who presented with infertility. During the procedure, the surgeon notices powder burn spots over the pelvic viscera. The diagnosis would be?
questions.solution:
Powder burn spots over pelvic viscera is seen in pelvic endometriosis. 

Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/gunshot appearance seen on the serosal surfaces of the peritoneum. They are black, dark brown, or bluish nodules or can be small cysts containing old hemorrhage surrounded by a variable degree of fibrosis.

Other pathology in Endometriosis:

  • Peritoneal cavity: contains yellowish-brown fluid which has prostaglandins responsible for the pain of endometriosis.
  • Ovary: Chocolate cyst (True cyst with columnar epithelium lining)

Powder burn appearance:

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year old friend from the same class  is afraid of contracting the disease.  What advice should be given to the exposed students?
questions.solution:
Antibiotic prophylaxis is provided to the close contacts of persons with confirmed meningococcal disease.

Treatment is provided to the contacts within 24 hours of identification of the index case. The antibiotics effective include rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, ceftriaxone, and azithromycin.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis of the condition given in the picture is posterior dislocation of left hip joint.

The radiograph shows the following findings:

  • The femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • The left femoral head appears slightly smaller than the right femoral head
  • The limb is adducted and internally rotated

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle?
questions.solution:
Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of normal sexual cycle.

In premature ejaculation, there is a persistent or recurrent achievementof orgasm and ejaculation before the patient actually wishes to. According to DSM-5, it is classified as follows:
  • Mild if ejaculation occurs within approximately 30 sec­onds to 1 minute of vaginal penetration
  • Moderate if ejaculation occurs within approximately 15 to 30 seconds of vaginal pen­etration
  • Severe if ejaculation occurs at the start of sexual activity or within approximately 15 seconds of vaginal penetra­tion.

Pharmacologic therapy when combined with behavioral treatment appears to be more effective in treating premature ejaculation. 

The squeeze technique is a behavioral method used on the penis to prevent premature ejaculation. Here, the penis is stimulated until just before orgasm after which it is gently squeezed. 

Related Pearl: Sexual disorders

Phase
Characteristics
Disorder
Treatment
Desire
Focuses on the patient's drives, motivation, and desires
Hypoactive sexual desire: Patients have a decrease or absence of sexual fantasies, desires, etc
 
Sexual aversion: A complete aversion to all sexual contact
Address issues like feelings of guilt, poor self-esteem, homosexual impulses, etc
 
Couples therapy may be indicated if due to marital conflict
Arousal
Consists of a sense of sexual pleasure with accompanying physiologic changes
Female sexual arousal disorder: Persistent failure to achieve or maintain sufficient sexual interest or arousal during the sexual act
 
Impotence: Persistent or recurrent inability to attain or maintain an adequate erection until completion of the sexual act
Address issues like guilt, anxiety, and fear
 
Check for use of medications that cause vaginal dryness, like antihistamines or anticholinergics
 
Relaxation techniques.
 
Determine if organic or psychological.
 
Consider plethysmography or postage stamp test
Orgasm
Physiologic state in which sexual tension is released and contractions are produced in various organs
Female orgasmic disorder and delayed ejaculation: Recurrent or persistent inability to achieve orgasm either through masturbation or sexual intercourse
 
Premature ejaculation: Ejaculation before the man wishes to do so, before penetration or just after penetration

Address issues of guilt, fear of impregnation, etc

Use vibrators, education, and fantasy

Behavioral techniques such as squeeze and stop-and-go

Address issues of anxiety about the sexual act

SSRIs to delay ejaculation
Pain
Subjective sense of pain associated with the sexual act. Most likely due to dynamic factors
Genito-pelvic pain disorder: Pain associated with sexual intercourse in either male or female. Not diagnosed when the organic cause has been found or if due to vaginal lubrication.
 
Penetration disorder: Involuntary constriction of the outer one-third of the vagina that interferes with the sexual act.

Help with issues of anxiety and tension about the sexual act

Behavioral techniques, such as the use of dilators and relaxation

Address issues of fear of impregnation, strict upbringing, religion, etc

questions.text: Which of the following inhaled anesthetics is the induction agent of choice in a patient planned for surgery under GA?
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane is the induction agent of choice among inhalational anesthetics. 

It is non-pungent and has low blood-gas solubility (0.65), allowing for smooth induction of anesthesia.

Option A: Halothane has high blood gas solubility, leading to a slower induction of anesthesia.

Option C: Desflurane and isoflurane are airway irritants, of which desflurane is the most pungent inhalational agent. Hence, they are not used for the induction of anesthesia as they can precipitate laryngospasm. These agents are used only during the maintenance of anesthesia.

Option D: N2O has a MAC value of 104%, which makes it the least potent inhaled anesthetic. It is always used in combination with more potent volatile agents.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice  
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Day care surgery Sevoflurane(preferred)/Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac disease Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane(preferred)/Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

Most potent      

 Methoxyflurane>Halothane 

Least potent     

 Nitrous oxide>Desflurane 

Most epileptogenic  

 Enflurane

Most nephrotoxic  

 Methoxyflurane 

Most hepatotoxic 

 Halothane

questions.text: In which of the following cases would you prescribe systemic corticosteroids?
questions.solution:
Impetigo herpetiformis (pustular psoriasis of pregnancy) is the only definitive indication for systemic steroids.

Steroids can also be used for the control of acute symptoms like ARDS accompanying pustular psoriasis.

Steroids are contraindicated in all other forms of psoriasis as sudden withdrawal can trigger severe pustular or erythrodermic psoriasis. As most of the other medications are contraindicated in pregnancy, this is the only definitive indication for systemic steroids.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Type Drug of choice
Chronic Plaque Psoriasis Methotrexate
Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate 
Psoriatic Arthritis Methotrexate / Apremilast
Pustular Psoriasis Acitretin
Psoriasis in HIV patients Acitretin
Impetigo Herpetiformis

1. Systemic Corticosteroids

2. Cyclosporine
Erythrodermic Psoriasis in Pregnancy Systemic Corticosteroids

questions.text: Identify the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T2 weighted image as the CSF appears bright/hyperintense and white matter appears dark. 

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, of which the most classic are T1 and T2 weighted images.

FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. As a result, CSF is dark. However, white matter is dark and grey matter is bright similar to T2 imaging.

STIR (short tau inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fat from T2. So, fat is dark. It is done to detect bone marrow edema in body part scans.

Related Pearl: T1 vs T2 MRI

Structure
T1 image
T2 image
Grey matter
Darker
 Lighter
White matter
 Lighter  Darker
CSF/ Fluids
Dark
Bright
Fat
White
Less white
Air
Dark
Dark
Cortical bone
Dark
Dark
Tendons and ligaments
Dark
Dark
Calcification
Dark
Dark
Flowing blood and hemosiderin
Dark
Dark

questions.text: Patients with which of the following tumors are best treated with radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Patients diagnosed with seminoma are best treated with radiotherapy, as it is a highly radiosensitive tumor. 

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: A female patient presents with numbness in her fingertips. On examination, her face appears tightened. The antinuclear antibody(ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence demonstrates a nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Numbness of fingers (associated with Raynaud's phenomenon), facial tightening, and positive anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) with nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence are highly suggestive of systemic sclerosis.

Systemic sclerosis/ scleroderma:

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune connective tissue disorder that results in fibrosis of the skin, vasculature, and internal organs. It is of two types, namely diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis and limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. 

Scleroderma is characterized by Raynaud's phenomenon, digital ischemia, sclerodactyly, calcinosis, telangiectasia, and cardiac, lung, gastrointestinal and renal disease. Skin thickening is the hallmark of SSc. Patients have a characteristic expressionless facial appearance with taut and shiny skin and microstomia.

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are positive in SSC. The presence of anti-topoisomerase 1 (Scl70) and anticentromere antibodies are seen in diffuse cutaneous SSC and limited cutaneous SSc respectively.

The nucleolar pattern of ANA staining in immunofluorescence is most commonly seen in systemic sclerosis. A centromeric pattern is also seen.

The image below shows the nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence seen in systemic sclerosis.

Other options:

Option B: Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of salivary and lacrimal glands. 

Patients present with dry eye (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia) due to fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary gland respectively.

Anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are positive in Sjogren's syndrome. ANA and RF (Rheumatoid factor) can also be seen. Centromeric patterns and speckled patterns of staining are seen in Sjogren's syndrome.

The image below shows a speckled pattern of staining.

Option C: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia with early morning stiffness. 

Other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis.

ANA, Anti-dsDNA antibodies, anti-smith antibodies are positive in SLE. Homogenous or diffuse staining and peripheral staining pattern are most commonly seen in SLE.

Image below shows a homogenous or diffuse stained immunofluorescence pattern seen in SLE.

Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a multisystem disease that classically presents with pain, joint swelling, and stiffness of the small joints of the hands, feet, and wrists in a symmetrical manner.

RF and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies are positive in RA. Homogenous staining is the most common pattern seen in RA.

Related Pearl: Manifestations of systemic sclerosis

Organ

Manifestations

Skin

Endothelial injury and microvascular disease causing chronic ischemia

Alimentary Tract

Affected in approximately 90% of patients.

Progressive atrophy and collagenous fibrous replacement of the muscular is most severe in the esophagus.

The lower two-thirds of the esophagus often develops a rubber-hose–like an inflexibility.

Gastroesophageal reflux and Barrett metaplasia and strictures.

Musculoskeletal System

Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the synovial soft tissues

Joint destruction is not common in systemic sclerosis.

Inflammatory myositis

Kidneys.

The most prominent are the vascular lesions.

Interlobular arteries show intimal thickening as a result of deposition of mucinous or finely collagenous material

Lungs.

The lungs are involved in more than 50% of individuals

Pulmonary hypertension and interstitial fibrosis

Pulmonary fibrosis

Heart

Pericarditis with effusion, myocardial fibrosis, and thickening of intramyocardial arterioles

questions.text: You were posted as a medical officer in a Kala-azar endemic area. There was a rise in the number of insects shown in the given image below. Identify the insect:
questions.solution:
The image given is that of a sandfly (Phlebotomus), which is the vector for Kala-azar.

Sandflies are generally small insects, light or dark brown in color. They are smaller than mosquitoes. Their body and wings are densely clothed with hair. Their wings are up-right and lanceolate in shape and their legs are longer compared with the size of the body. They hop about and do not fly much. The species of sandfly responsible for transmitting the disease kala-azar is Phlebotomus argentipes. 

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection mainly affecting the reticuloendothelial system. It is caused by various species of the genus Leishmania. It can present as visceral leishmaniasis, cutaneous leishmaniasis, ad mucosal leishmaniasis. Clinical features of the visceral form include moderate to high-grade fever with chills and rigors, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. 

The gold standard test for the diagnosis is the demonstration of amastigotes in the smears of tissue aspirates. Another commonly used test is the detection of antibodies to a recombinant antigen called rK39 by a rapid immunochromatographic test. In immunocompromised individuals, parasites can be isolated from the buffy coat. Amphotericin B is the first-line drug used in India. 

Other diseases transmitted by sandflies include sandfly fever and oriental sore.

For the reduction of sandflies, a  single application of DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) or lindane has been found effective. 

Other options:

Option A: Tsetse flies or glossinae are the blood-sucking flies that resemble the common houseflies. They are yellow or dark-brown in color. When folded, their wings overlap each other like the blade of a scissor. They have a non-retractile proboscis which is rigid and adapted for piercing the skin and sucking the blood. They are vectors for trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness and are only found in regions in Africa.

 

Option C- Rat flea is the vector for plague and typhus. They are wingless, their head is conical in shape, and is directly attached to the thorax without a neck. The head has piercing mouth parts that are conspicuous and project downward for sucking blood. They have 3 pairs of legs attached to the thorax. 

Option D: Black flies are small robust flies. They are black short stout legs, large broad wings, and a short proboscis to suck blood. They are the vectors of onchocerciasis in Africa, Mexico, Central, and South America.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever and oraya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

Related Pearl: Arthropod-borne Diseases

Mosquito Malaria, filaria, Japanese encephalitis, dengue, West Nile fever, yellow fever, etc.
Housefly Typhoid, paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever, oraya fever.
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus (murine typhus), hymenolepis diminuta.
Blackfly (Simulum) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug (Kissing bug/Triatominae) Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, Kyasanur forest disease, tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF)
Soft tick Relapsing fever
Ixodes tick Lyme disease, babesiosis and anaplasmosis.
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus
House mouse mite Rickettsial pox
Itch mite Scabies
Cyclops Guinea worm disease, fish tapeworm
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrans, jigger or chigoe flea) Tungiasis, ulcers in feet/nails.

questions.text: While collecting blood for samples, you spilled some on the floor. The next step would be to clean it with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite solution is used to decontaminate blood-spilled surfaces. The concentrations of sodium hypochlorite used are: 

  • < 10 mL blood spill - 1:100 dilution to decontaminate non-porous surfaces
  • > 10 mL blood spill or culture spill - 1:10 dilution for the first application, followed by 1:100 dilution

Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills; it is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labeled containment. 

Related Pearl: Methods of sterilisation

Method of disinfection or sterilisation Material
Red Heat Inoculating wire loop, tip of forceps
Incineration Contaminated clothes, animal carcasses, plastics like PVC, polythene
Hot air oven Glasswares, scalpels, forceps, cutting instruments, test tubes
Inspissator Heat labile culture media containing egg, sugar or serum
Autoclave Culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut
Isopropyl alcohol Clinical thermometers, stethoscopes, probes
Methyl alcohol Fungal spores

Beta propiolactone/

formaldehyde

 Fumigation of operating theatres, wards and labs
2% gluteraldehyde Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, fibre-optic endoscopes, plastic ETT, face masks
Plasma sterilisation Arthroscopes, urethroscopes
Ethylene oxide Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments, sutures, books, clothings
Filtration (Seitz filters) Bacterial vaccines, intravenous solutions
5% cresol, hot air oven Sharp instruments

Ionising radiation

(Cold air sterilization)

 Catgut, swabs, plastic, syringes, needles, gloves, catheters, grafts
Chlorhexidine Disinfecting surgeon’s hands prior to surgery
Iodophor Disinfecting surgical site prior to surgery
70% ethanol Disinfectant skin prior to venepuncture or immunisation
Thiomersal Preservative in vaccine
Silver sulfadiazine Cleanse burn wounds
Hypochlorite Cleanup of blood spill from a patient with hepatitis B or C
Hydrogen peroxide Cleanse wounds
